title: Enhancing Resolution in STEM EELS Hyperspectral Data through Rigid Image Registration
content: Advanced techniques in a scanning transmission electron microscope (STEM), such as electron energy-loss spectroscopy (EELS) and four-dimensional STEM (4D-STEM), yield multidimensional hyperspectral data that provides valuable insights into the electron and vibrational structures of materials [1]. Recently, Nion’s monochromated EELS-STEM system has achieved a remarkable combination of an energy resolution of 2.6 meV and a spatial resolution of 1.1 Å at 20 kV [2]. Despite these advancements, the low beam current of the monochromated electron probe leads to a long acquisition time for EELS hyperspectral datasets, from 30 minutes to a few hours, to reach a good signal-to-noise ratio. Consequently, such extended durations introduce noticeable sample drifts, especially in atomic resolution tasks. To address this issue, we propose a rigid image registration-based algorithm. By aligning the vibrational EELS hyperspectral dataset, we can compensate for drift and minimize image distortion due to the effects of thermal drifting and beam charging. As a result, we can now achieve arbitrarily long exposure datasets with improved atomic features.
